channel.title: Dread Pirates Society
channel.description: Lessons from life on board the pirate ship Revenge

item.title: Encrypt Your Browser Profile Directory
item.description: by Miracle Max - For some added security, you can create a separate browser profile for browsing the dark web and then encrypt it using EncFS. If you use gnome-encfs-manager and a little bash scripting, you can have the encrypted drive automatically unmounted after you close the browser. As a play-on-words, I like to...

item.title: Stop Disrespecting Rosemary!
item.description: by Vizzini - Have you ever used rosemary in your cooking? Do you know how strong this herb is? It’s very strong. A little of this stuff goes a long way. A very long way. It’s very easy to over-power a dish with too much rosemary; you only need a few leaves. Then...

item.title: Fixed My Simple Tor Outproxy For I2P Using DeleGate
item.description: by Miracle Max - A while ago, I wrote about using the tiny proxy DeleGate. I mentioned that it seemed to work as an i2p outproxy, but I was seeing missing images and css. Well, I figured out what was happening. Original Post: Creating an i2P Tor Outproxy with DeleGate The problem So it...

item.title: Quick Command-Line View Of i2pSnark Torrents
item.description: by Miracle Max - Ever want to check the status of your i2pSnark torrents without firing up a browser? I did, and here’s a python script I made to do that. snark #!/usr/bin/python3 import requests, sys, re from bs4 import BeautifulSoup from pprint import pprint mode = 'NotSeeding' #default searchstring = None if len(sys.argv)...

item.title: David Fish Dies - U.S. Dividend Champions List Future Uncertain
item.description: by Prince Humperdinck - Sadly, David Fish, who published the monthly U.S. Dividend Champions list over at dripinvesting.org died on May 12, 2018. Fish’s spreadsheet formed the backbone of my dividend riches screener and I’d been worried about what would happen to the list when he eventually died. Justin Law posted an updated spreadsheet...

item.title: Strealine Your Wardrobe With a Simple Rule-Based Method... and Paperclips
item.description: by Westley - I was inspired by a section of the book Early Retirement Extreme where the author talks about streamlining your life by getting rid of unused possession. The basic idea was that by having fewer possessions, you can save money by living in a smaller place and also get some money...

item.title: Using The Midori NoJS Extension With I2P
item.description: by Miracle Max - Uncheck Set permissions on second-level domain in the NoJS preferences or else it won’t recognize i2p sites. Background I use midori as my main browser. It’s small, quick, and loads fast. It also comes with some useful extensions such as an ad-blocker and an extension that controls whether javascript is...

item.title: Simple Statistical Analysis With Python
item.description: by Count Rugen - It’s sometimes handy to see if there’s a significant relationship between two things in your life. Perhaps it’s calories eaten and weight lost; or maybe it’s the P/E ratio of a stock and it’s subsequent 1-year growth. Who knows. It’s actually pretty easy to use the scipy library for python...

item.title: Dividend Riches Statistics
item.description: by Prince Humperdinck - After grabbing the historical U.S. Champions spreadsheets, I decided to do a little back-testing of the screens I had developed (see Automated Screening for Dividend Riches). Summary Statistically speaking, investing in the top three categories is highly likely to be superior to investing in the S&P 500 or the Russell...

item.title: Automated Screening For Dividend Riches
item.description: by Prince Humperdinck - A while ago, I reviewed a book called Get Rich with Dividends. In it, the author presents some sensible criteria for finding stable dividend-producing investments. The basic criteria for choosing investments are: Dividend Yield >= 4.7% Average Annualized Dividend Growth over the last 10 years >= 10% Payout Ratio: Annual...

item.title: Liquidating My Individual Investment Accounts
item.description: by humperdinck - As a young investor with dreams of increasing my fortune through investing, I put a lot of my money in an individual (taxable) investment account. This meant I could (hopefully) grow my funds, but still have access to them; unlike with a (tax-sheltered) retirement account. I knew that a better...
